DOC.HEAD: Suspected Leader of Drug Death Squads Arrested
DOC.TEXT: The chief of the death squads organized by the Medellin cocaine cartel was arrested at a police roadblock in central Colombia, authorities said Sunday. Elsewhere, battles between leftist guerrillas and security forces left eight rebels and four soldiers dead, radio reports said. In other violence, a bomb exploded early Sunday in Bogota, destroying two cars, the national police said in a statement. No one claimed responsibility for the attack. The latest drug-trafficking suspect to be arrested was Jose Manuel Cruz Aguirre, chief of the Medellin cartel's right-wing death squads, who is wanted in Peru, the Administrative Security police said in a separate communique. Aguirre was arrested Friday night on a highway about 35 miles south of Bogota, the security police said. There were no immediate details on what charges he faces. Death squads financed by drug traffickers have killed scores of peasants suspected of sympathizing with leftist guerrillas, who have tried to extort cattle ranchers in areas where traffickers hold property. The death squads also have killed about 740 members of the country's biggest leftist political party, the Patriotic Union, presumably because the party has the support of the country's estimated 10,000 leftist guerrillas. Aguirre also was part owner of one of Colombia's professional soccer teams, Deportes Tolima, the security police said. Colombian authorities have claimed for years that drug bosses are among owners of several professional soccer teams in Colombia. Aguirre was the third purported member of the Medellin cartel arrested in four days. The others were Jose Antonio Ocampo Obando and Camilo Antonio Ruiz Vega. Ocampo Obando, arrested Friday, is considered by Colombian authorities to be the fifth most important member of the Medellin cartel. He is wanted for extradition by the United States, police said last week. Ruiz Vega was a top confidant of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, the No. 2 leader of the Medellin Cartel who was killed by police Dec. 15. On Saturday, police confiscated a 25,000-acre ranch belonging to Rodriguez Gacha in the central state of Tolima, the security police also said in their communique Sunday. The biggest battle between guerrillas and the army was Saturday near the Caribbean coastal town of Turbo, the Defense Ministry said. Six guerrillas of the Popular Liberation Army and two soldiers were killed, the Colombian radio networks RCN and Caracol quoted the military command as saying. Also Saturday, guerrillas from the same group ambushed an army patrol in northeastern Colombia, the radio networks quoted the army's 5th Brigade headquarters in Bucaramanga as saying. They said two guerillas and two soldiers were killed. The People's Liberation Army is one of six guerrilla groups in Colombia and claims it adheres to Maoist Chinese doctrine.
